review.title: Potential Functions based Sampling Heuristic For Optimal Path Planning
review.abstract: Rapidly-exploring Random Tree Star(RRT*) is a recently proposed extension of Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (RRT) algorithm that provides a collision-free, asymptotically optimal path regardless of obstacle's geometry in a given environment. However, one of the limitations in the RRT* algorithm is slow convergence to optimal path solution. As a result, it consumes high memory as well as time due to a large number of iterations utilised in achieving optimal path solution. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Potential Function Based-RRT* (P-RRT*) that incorporates the Artificial Potential Field Algorithm in RRT*. The proposed algorithm allows a considerable decrease in the number of iterations and thus leads to more efficient memory utilization and an accelerated convergence rate. In order to illustrate the usefulness of the proposed algorithm in terms of space execution and convergence rate, this paper presents rigorous simulation based comparisons between the proposed techniques and RRT* under different environmental conditions. Moreover, both algorithms are also tested and compared under non-holonomic differential constraints.
histories: This paper introduces a novel algorithm called P-RRT*. The work has been published in Springer Autonomous Robots Journal
review.COMMENTS: This paper introduces a novel algorithm called P-RRT*. The work has been published in Springer Autonomous Robots Journal

metadata.title: Potential Functions based Sampling Heuristic For Optimal Path Planning

sections.text: Fast Exploration Random Tree Star (RRT *) is a recently proposed extension of the Fast Exploration Random Tree (RRT *) algorithm, which provides a collision-free, asymptotically optimal path regardless of obstacle geometry in a given environment. To overcome these limitations, we propose the potential Function Based RRT * (P-RRT *), which incorporates the artificial potential field algorithm in RRT *. The proposed algorithm allows for a significant reduction in the number of iterations, resulting in more efficient memory usage and an accelerated convergence rate. To illustrate the usefulness of the proposed algorithm, this is the version of the paper published in Springer Autonomous Robots Journal. The source code for this paper is also available under various conditions.

sections.heading: 6.3 Fast convergence to optimal path solution
sections.text: This section analyzes the P-RRT * algorithm for its ability to solve a problem by ensuring near-rapid convergence to an optimal solution of the problem. To understand the concept of fast convergence, a few new terms are introduced that can be defined as follows. Allow any random configuration to be defined as a random state if the ball region of the Xfree radius is partially centered in a barrier-free space if the ball region of the radius δ is centered in x completely in a barrier-free space. sections.heading: 6.4 Computational Complexity
sections.text: This section aims to compare the computational complexities of P-RT * and RRT *. Let SRRT * n and SP − RRT * n denote the number of steps performed per iteration n by RRT * and P-RRT *. In the proposed algorithm, the only additional procedure is RGD (xinit), while the rest of the procedures are exactly the same number of steps used by RRT *. Therefore, only the RGD (xinit) procedure is analyzed for its computational load. It should be noted that the procedures in the RGD function can be executed in a constant number of steps and are independent of the number of nodes present in the tree. Furthermore, the algorithm must calculate the next obstacle configuration from any random state x-Xfree (equation 3).

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future work
sections.text: The RRT * ensures asymptotic optimality, but is not a memory-efficient algorithm and has a low convergence rate. Potential function-based RRT * (P-RRT *) addresses this problem and provides a solution by incorporating the artificial potential field algorithm into the RRT *. Both experimentally and analytically, our proposed P-RRT * algorithm has been proven to have (i) the same asymptotic computational complexity as the RRT *; (ii) inherit asymptotic optimality from the RRT *; (iii) no local minimum problem; (iv) faster convergence to the optimal path solution compared to the RRT *; (v) uses less memory by sufficiently reducing the number of iterations required and time required to calculate an optimized solution compared to the RRT *.

This paper introduces the idea of potentially guided, directionalized sampling by incorporating Artificial Potential Field Algorithm (APF) [8] into RRT*, thus resulting into guided exploration of given environment.

Artificial Potential Field (APF) algorithms are known for their simplicity and strong mathematical analysis but their applications are limited to a state space of up to five dimensions due to its inability to work in local minima environments [9].

However, one of the limitation in the RRT* algorithm is slow convergence to optimal path solution. As a result it consumes high memory as well as time due to the large number of iterations utilised in achieving optimal path solution. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Potential Function Based-RRT* (P-RRT*) that incorporates the Artificial Potential Field Algorithm in RRT*. The proposed algorithm allows a considerable decrease in the number of iterations and thus leads to more efficient memory utilization and an accelerated convergence rate.
